DataElement.preferredName: Dose Integer::25 Gray Duodenum Radiation Therapy Exposure Percentage Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric value for the percentage of duodenal volume receiving 25 Gray (GY) dosage of radiation.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time._A number with no fractional part.::25_The SI derived unit of absorbed radiation dose. One gray is equal to an absorbed dose of one joule per kilogram of matter; one gray equals 100 rads. The unit is named for the British physician L. Harold Gray, an authority on the use of radiation in the treatment of cancer._A jointed tube 25-30 cm long that connects the stomach to the jejunum._Contact with infectious agents (bacteria or viruses) in a manner that promotes transmission and increases the likelihood of disease. (CDC)

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The amount of medicine taken, or radiation given, at one time.:A number with no fractional part.::25:The SI derived unit of absorbed radiation dose. One gray is equal to an absorbed dose of one joule per kilogram of matter; one gray equals 100 rads. The unit is named for the British physician L. Harold Gray, an authority on the use of radiation in the treatment of cancer.

Concepts.definition: A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time.
A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
A SI derived unit of absorbed radiation dose. One gray is equal to an absorbed dose of one joule per kilogram of matter, or to 100 rads.

Property.preferredDefinition: (doo-ah-DEE-num) The first part of the small intestine.:Contact with infectious agents (bacteria or viruses) in a manner that promotes transmission and increases the likelihood of disease. (CDC)

Concepts.definition: A jointed tube 25-30 cm long that connects the stomach to the jejunum.
The act of subjecting someone or something to an influencing experience.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredName: Anatomic Site Radiation Therapy Exposure Percentage Value
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Named locations of or within the body._(RAY-dee-AY-shun) The use of high-energy radiation from x-rays, gamma rays, neutrons, and other sources to kill cancer cells and shrink tumors. Radiation may come from a machine outside the body (external-beam radiation therapy) or from materials called radioisotopes. Radioisotopes produce radiation and can be placed in or near the tumor or in the area near cancer cells. This type of radiation treatment is called internal radiation therapy, implant radiation, interstitial radiation, or brachytherapy. Systemic radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance, such as a radiolabeled monoclonal antibody, that circulates throughout the body._Contact with infectious agents (bacteria or viruses) in a manner that promotes transmission and increases the likelihood of disease. (CDC)_Percentage; a fraction or ratio with 100 understood as the denominator._A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Anatomic Site Radiation Therapy Exposure Percentage Value
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Named locations of, or within, the body.:use PHOTOTHERAPY, LASER THERAPY, or ULTRAVIOLET THERAPY for therapeutic radiation with visible, laser, or ultraviolet light, respectively.:Contact with infectious agents (bacteria or viruses) in a manner that promotes transmission and increases the likelihood of disease. (CDC):Percentage; a fraction or ratio with 100 understood as the denominator.:A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: Named locations of or within the body.

Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.
The act of subjecting someone or something to an influencing experience.
A fraction or ratio with 100 understood as the denominator.
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

DataElement.changeDescription: Curated to support Lombardi Cancer Center Cyberknife study.
